itemContext.sbar: S: Jane Doe, 48-year-old female, admitted at 03:00 for altered mental status. History of Graves' disease, recently discontinued methimazole against medical advice. B: Patient found at home confused and diaphoretic. Glucose via glucometer was HI. EMS report indicates rapid heart rate and agitation. Patient was not wearing a mask. A: 07:00 assessment reveals: HR 180 bpm, BP 190/110 mmHg, RR 32 breaths/min (deep and rapid), Temp 104.5°F (40.3°C). Patient is restless, confused, and exhibiting tremors. STAT lab results are pending. O2 saturation is 92% on room air. Droplet precautions initiated due to elevated temperature and unknown infectious etiology. P: Anticipate orders for IV fluids, cooling measures, and medications to address potential thyroid storm. Monitor for signs of respiratory distress and cardiac arrhythmias. Contact provider immediately with lab results.

tabs.title: Labs
tabs.content: Na+: 148 mEq/L, K+: 3.2 mEq/L, Cl-: 105 mEq/L, Glucose: 650 mg/dL, BUN: 30 mg/dL, Creatinine: 1.8 mg/dL, pH: 7.30, pCO2: 30 mmHg, HCO3-: 16 mEq/L, TSH: <0.01 uIU/mL, Free T4: 7.0 ng/dL

tabs.title: MAR
tabs.content: Scheduled: Methimazole 5mg PO daily (discontinued), Multivitamin PO daily. PRN: Acetaminophen 650mg PO q4h PRN for fever, Ondansetron 4mg IV q6h PRN for nausea.

tabs.title: Vitals
tabs.content: 07:00: HR 180 bpm, BP 190/110 mmHg, RR 32 breaths/min, Temp 104.5°F (40.3°C), SpO2 92% RA, GCS 12 (E3 V4 M5)

rationale.correct: The patient's presentation (fever, tachycardia, hypertension, altered mental status, low TSH, high Free T4) is most consistent with thyroid storm, a life-threatening exacerbation of hyperthyroidism. The priority nursing intervention is to manage the hyperthermia and cardiovascular instability. This includes administering antithyroid medications (PTU or methimazole), beta-blockers (propranolol) to control heart rate, and cooling measures to reduce fever. Untreated thyroid storm can lead to heart failure and death.
rationale.incorrect: DKA and HHS are incorrect because while hyperglycemia is present, the primary driver of the patient's condition is the thyroid hormone excess. Although the patient has acidosis, it is not the primary problem. The patient’s labs show a low TSH and high Free T4 level, indicating hyperthyroidism. While managing hyperglycemia is important, it is not the priority over stabilizing the cardiovascular system and reducing thyroid hormone levels. Hypothyroidism is the opposite of the patient’s presentation. The patient has hyperthermia, tachycardia, and elevated Free T4 levels.
clinicalPearls: Thyroid storm is a medical emergency requiring prompt recognition and treatment.
Beta-blockers are used to control the adrenergic symptoms of thyroid storm (tachycardia, hypertension).
Cooling blankets and acetaminophen are used to manage hyperthermia.

questionTrap.trap: Focusing solely on the elevated glucose level might lead to considering DKA or HHS, overlooking the more critical thyroid-related symptoms.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Carefully analyze all lab values, vital signs, and the patient's history of Graves' disease. Prioritize conditions that pose the most immediate threat to the patient's life.

mnemonic.title: Thyroid STORM
mnemonic.expansion: Stress/Surgery, Trauma, Obstetric complications, Radioiodine therapy, Missed medication, infection, drugs (amiodarone).
